Articles.Content:
Cavemen Are From Duna

My orbital mechanic knowledge has grown but I can admit that there is so very much more to learn. 

Thanks goes to GoSlash27 for showing us the way of the caveman and all the cavemen in the [KSP Caveman Challenge](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/127795-KSP-Caveman-Challenge!) for inspiration and tossing a pebble that hit rock that hit stone then a hit that started a boulder rolling.

After using pork chop maps and maneuver nodes to travel to Duna I am now trying to get there with limited technology and no facility upgrades. The "caveman" technology has no building upgrades. The fully loaded Kickback SRB cannot be handled by the VAB/SPH team. Everything will be assembled with docking ports on land and in orbit. The tracking station and mission control offer some assistance but no targeting a celestial body. Rocks are what cavemen know.

**The idea is to boldly go interplanetary with "cavemen" and their technology.**

To use successive approximation and launch shotgun style and carve out a path for the following rocks(probes) which will then narrow the path for the Duna Boulder Explorer. The probes will allow for course correction by following the probe that makes an intercept. The probes that do not make intercept are used as the limits. More extra fuel will follow and is being sent as remotes probes for plotting and navigating the return to Kerbin.

**Plotting a course to Duna**

Calculations for the Duna transfer window will allow a reasonable attempt to intercept Duna.

The Duna transfer window requires calculations of: phase angle, ejection velocity and ejection angle.

First send a fleet of rocks (probes) to gauge the calculations for the Duna transfer window. This preliminary data is essential before going further.

The following years close to the launch window eight probes will be sent on intercept with Duna.

The probes that make near misses are tracked and their orbital paths outline a window that lead to Duna.

Probes that intercept Duna will have the flight data heavily scrutinized.

 This successive approximation technique will start to illustrate a boundary and a clear path the Duna Boulder Explorer should take.

Prior to and following the launch of Duna Boulder Explorer another fleet of probes will be used to scout and guide the team to facilitate course corrections.

 **** **The Duna Boulder Explorer**

Hitchhiker crew quarters, command pod and lander module will be assembled in low Kerbin orbit. The design will use four Poodle engines and drop tanks that will be reduced to a pair of the "Poodle" engines for the voyage home. 

The Duna Boulder Explorer is intended to have a lander go to the surface and return. Upon return the drop tank is replaced with another and the lander will return to the surface and return. Landings for Ike are also planned.

**Vessel Assembly**

Modular rocket building is a method that allows grand scales that the current VAB/SPH team cannot deal with due to union rules and a crappy facility.

The Kickback SRB must have about a third of its fuel removed just for VAB/SPH handling.

Outside and far away from the facilities the union doesn't care as long as no VAB/SPH employee are in danger. 

 The pieces will be assembled on the Vehicle Assembly Lawn and then brought together for final assembly at the launchpad.

The initial vessels launched will be fuel and engines for the voyage. These will be docked in low kerbin orbit and finally the hitchhiker crew quarters, command pod and lander module will be launched and brought together and assembled. 

**Planning Phase and Construction Feasibility**

 **Initial Testing**

This evidence that fuel can be attached and used exclusively. This allows for vessels to incorporate drop tanks. Refueling the vessel is completed by docking with another drop tank.

The vessel assembly and strength of the docking port was tested. This test also revealed the fuel flow direction issue. 

![XTU4h7M.png](http://i.imgur.com/XTU4h7M.png)

**Tools for exploration**

Bill has a bag of tricks available but some might prove incompatible with the current technology.

![ygWw2qs.png](http://i.imgur.com/ygWw2qs.png)

The use of a simulator has been used for feasibility testing but for this mission it will be limited. Thinking about just using essentials such as Delta V and Horizontal speed with altimeter. Apoapsis/Periapsis indicators and would also be helpful. Bill is not sure what else to take.

 **The Vehicle Assembly Lawn**

The VAL can cause many headaches and has many things to educate by failure.

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/Hd5br)

**Staging Logic Left**

Getting to space has never been this hard. Discoveries were made that advanced the logic of staging via Clamp-o-tron docking port junior.

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/jhd9x)

**Duna Missions**

**Duna Scouts and Rangers**

The initial flights will have vessels consisting of five rocks (probes) attempt to intercept Duna.

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/AK56J)

Five Rocks IV In Space

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/lXEzY)

[Five Rocks IV Flawless Launch Victory](https://vimeo.com/137721544)

<iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/137721544" width="1280" height="720" frameborder="0" title="Five Rocks" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-30T03:55:33Z" title="08/30/2015 03:55  AM" data-short="8 yr">August 30, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

Egad, what a challenge. Ingenious idea there about shotgunning probes to eyeball phase angles. Are you going to take another batch with you so you can figure out how to get back to Kerbin?

Do you have a video of how you're building stuff outside the VAB? I couldn't figure it out from the pics.

> 
> Are you going to take another batch with you so you can figure out how to get back to Kerbin?
> Do you have a video of how you're building stuff outside the VAB?

The idea was envisioned after seeing that massive fleet that Jolly\_Roger sent out to Eve.

[Shotgun](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/129260-KSP-Wasn-t-Designed-For-This)

![GpJv44e.png](http://i.imgur.com/GpJv44e.png)

The plan is to lightly use the save/load for glitches and other similar mishaps. The hit and miss of the initial phase angle testing could be down with quicksaves just to speed things up. since I already know Duna should be slightly ahead at around 30 degree this initial phase is being skipped.

The plan does include probes for the return. Probes will be sent out from Kerbin and from the Duna Boulder Explorer. 

The video of the initial test construction and the more recent builds, this will be posted soon.

This is the construction kit that was ordered and the wrapping comes off tonight. \*sniff\*Ahhh. It has that new cave smell.

![j0xvdxR.png](http://i.imgur.com/j0xvdxR.png)

The kit contains a cart that is two pieces a Frame and an Engineering Room. The Brace has four hydraulic stabilizers. The top most engine is a Poodle along with fuel and bottom decoupler and Junior Docking port. The fuel cans below will be held by launch clamps and then attached to the cart and taken from the runway to the launchpad where the top stage is waiting. The bottom Skipper will be attached similarly. The whole assembly with two braces will be moved off the launch pad and three other boosters will be created.

Even though the kit contains four jet engines Bill has ordered four more. If anything goes wrong we are blaming Bill, because he has not revealed how he plans to attach the payload above these boosters.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-03T00:46:47Z" title="08/03/2015 12:46  AM" data-short="8 yr">August 3, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**
  
kerbal it
Subscribed. Because

@Bev7787

That [video of your cavemen throwing a rock at Duna](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/127795-KSP-Caveman-Challenge!?p=2115101&viewfull=1#post2115101) is spectacular. Seeing that intercept has put some fire in Bill's boots.
Thanks. I hope Bill is well.

Bill experimented with the cart and started getting the wild look in his eyes.

Bill could not resist taking the grinders and welders out. He made some modifications to improve the design. 

Now the cart has wider wheel base, two jet engines for additional braking and rocket powered Engineering room.

Bill got a good nights rest and is anxious to try out his modifications.

![i71buVB.png](http://i.imgur.com/i71buVB.png)

[Bill's Modded Cart](http://i.imgur.com/i71buVB.png)

After a few more of Bills last minute changes the cart was finally assembled and a Fuel Tank was loaded onto the cart. Compared to than the previous design this design was more stable for the Engineering Room but less stable when fully assembled and loaded. The whole thing was recorded with OBS and due to low drive space (way too many videos of initial testing) the file was unrecoverable. About three hours of footage were lost.

But here are somethings that were recorded successfully.

[Docking Port Magic](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/130583-Fuel-Flow-with-Rockets-and-Turbines-and-Docking-Port-Juniors?p=2118934#post2118934)

Investigating the docking port junior. 

[Thumper Rock](https://vimeo.com/135336890) 

[https://vimeo.com/135336890](https://vimeo.com/135336890)

Early Testing of the probe design. The BACC "Thumper" Solid Rocket Booster allows the assembled vessel additional structural strength. A cluster of probes are destined for intercept with Duna. This cluster is being assembled outside the Vertical Assembly Building and Space Plane Hanger.

With a fuel reserve waiting in LKO, the Thumper Rock cluster will first rendezvous and dock with it in low Kerbin orbit and then wing it to Duna;

https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/130583-Fuel-Flow-with-Rockets-and-Turbines-and-Docking-Port-Juniors?p=2118934#post2118934

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-04T09:05:21Z" title="08/04/2015 09:05  AM" data-short="8 yr">August 4, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

Bill made a few more modifications after he caused some explosions. ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)

This was the initial test and everything started to click together.

The cart is made up from three pieces. The Drone Cart is attached to the Engineering Room then that assembly is attached to the Thumper Cart. 

The Thumper cart will be used to haul up to 90 tonne weight and 20 metre height stack of assembled rocket.

 Pictured is the Thumper Cart being attached to a Kickback Brace that has four hydraulic legs and are designed when used as a pair to hold a completed rocket assembly. 

![qRacEpO.png](http://i.imgur.com/qRacEpO.png)

Bill has demonstrated that construction can be scaled up. The next test to be done is construct a rocket using two Kickbacks and two Thunpers attached to a core rocket probe. 

Staging is done through the docking ports. Prepare staging by using the Alt+RMB click to and load up the Decouple Button before launch instead of trying to target them while in flight. All successive detachments are to be done outside the atmosphere.

 All decouple buttons could be displayed then use the F2 to a clear view and see what is happening and then return back to the instrument display.

![lFuX8c2.png](http://i.imgur.com/lFuX8c2.png)

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/fVsvK)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-05T15:09:52Z" title="08/05/2015 03:09  PM" data-short="8 yr">August 5, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**
How do you ground dock? I'm trying to get my Laythe ship ground docked but I can't

Tonight I will be building this rocket in the way of the caveman.

![PYaFahJ.png](http://i.imgur.com/PYaFahJ.png)

The core is held in place with launch clamps at the Launch Pad and the Kickbacks and then the Thumpers will be delivered from the Runway. The Thumper cart will not be used at this time. Instead the Engineering Room will have an attachment installed that will allow transport and installation of the Kickback and Thumper SRB's

@Bev7787 The above should be clear on how I am doing this, but stay tuned I will be posting a video.

Here is a tid bit from the video Land Docking Fun

Never **Undock** an active Thumper SRB. Instead use **Decouple Node**.

![lYsdyVT.png](http://i.imgur.com/lYsdyVT.png)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-05T07:01:54Z" title="08/05/2015 07:01  AM" data-short="8 yr">August 5, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**
Ok thanks

Surface docking cab be accomplished using either horizontal or vertical approach. In either case having control in the vertical plane is important for the final docking sequence. When attempting to connect docking ports a brief change in height can bring the two together. Wheels that retract or landing legs can help facilitate this brief vertical movement.

For a horizontal approach on an even surface which have both ports aligned. Drift slowly towards the stationary port and be certain the ports are not askew. Brake just in front and let the magnets pull the two together.

With the surface uneven as it is at the runway vertical docking is accomplished with a stationary docking port on top and then the lower port moving upwards. The two docking ports need to be very close together but should not make contact the magnetic force needs to pull them together. Having the stationary docking port at the bottom then the top port might have to be lifted briefly. 

With landing gear it is possible to crouch and move forward. Duty cycle the Gears button while moving forward and stay at a crouch and make the docking port connection.

I have the docking port slightly lower on my carts. Someone with OCD at the SPH/VAB always releases the parking brake. The carts have to have its wheels retracted to prevent it from rolling away. The launch clamp or probe core could be attached but that wastes one part. Using the small gear bay the Engineering Room crouches briefly and makes the connection. The cart also doubles as a launch platform for the finished rocket. The wheels are retracted and the rocket should be suspended above the ground and stable.

[When the job is completed Bill lights off fireworks.](https://vimeo.com/135479373) 

[https://vimeo.com/135479373](https://vimeo.com/135479373)

This experience has changed my outlook on construction using docking ports. Before I considered rocket building outside the VAB/SPH too much a chore and headache. The gizmos in the VAB/SPH have brought me 180 degree and now see this as so much a part of the kerbal experience. 

 Use launch clamps to hold a component and then a cart loads up and delivers it to the launch pad where the surface is level and assembly easier. This allows for the VAB/SPH personnel to produce rocket components and Bill and other engineers to construct. If it was not for all those pesky VAB/SPH personnel Bill could have build it inside. Never seen rain or wind on Kerbin yet, so building outside is acceptable.

 When the parts started to join in my initial trials I was excited and the outlook was positive, however, after launching an assembled rocket the outlook quickly turned negative. Only having one docking port as a radial connection made a flimsy rocket. When a two part Clamp-O-tron connection was made this opened up new possibilities. The decouple feature is also very important. **Never undock an active or depleted booster**. Next was the use of the Kickback SRB for structural support and by trimming the fuel can also be used as a booster. Building a cart that can transport 18 tonne is also important. 

It would be interesting to see if engineers could have construction buffs similar to pilots and scientists. Fix a tire or repack a chute is nowhere near as awesome as breaking the limits using Kerbal Rocket Konstruction techniques. Maybe an even smaller docking port or light duty connection node with no decouple and engineers make and break connections. The parts still need to be moved into place just as in docking but are joined only when the engineer connects them. The Mod KAS/KIS looks to be on the list to try in the next career.

For now back to building the bag of rocks (cluster of probes) I plan on chucking towards Duna.

Bill has been pressured to reveal his plans for payload attachment. He says he is going to build a **Gruidae.**

![EJQNMDT.png](http://i.imgur.com/EJQNMDT.png)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-05T23:05:55Z" title="08/05/2015 11:05  PM" data-short="8 yr">August 5, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

Before construction starts on Thumper Rock Bill plans on to first build a scaled down design to work out any issues with rocket construction.

![HEP1uh9.png](http://i.imgur.com/HEP1uh9.png)

![QzJ6RXb.png](http://i.imgur.com/QzJ6RXb.png)

The turf in front of Gene's office has some major rut damage. 

 He should not be too mad at Bill when he sees this rocket take off in the morning.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-07T04:21:00Z" title="08/07/2015 04:21  AM" data-short="8 yr">August 7, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

Bill connected one Thumper and woke Jebediah up for help with the next. Jeb was cool because his ride looks better than Bill's.

![ktaU5JW.png](http://i.imgur.com/ktaU5JW.png)

Bill is excited as Jebediah makes the final connection.

Clear the Launch Pad!

![on3gXWG.png](http://i.imgur.com/on3gXWG.png)

Now to wait until dawn.

![9bAPUN2.png](http://i.imgur.com/9bAPUN2.png)

![LFcbxzx.png](http://i.imgur.com/LFcbxzx.png)

![X2jBHge.png](http://i.imgur.com/X2jBHge.png)

![oIxvqrt.png](http://i.imgur.com/oIxvqrt.png)

![DfMkWpc.png](http://i.imgur.com/DfMkWpc.png)

![gzHKZYE.png](http://i.imgur.com/gzHKZYE.png)

Go for launch!

Ignition!

![SGHCBP1.png](http://i.imgur.com/SGHCBP1.png)

Blast Off!

![JSPXyda.png](http://i.imgur.com/JSPXyda.png)

![IkUNPdH.png](http://i.imgur.com/IkUNPdH.png)

Never Undock boosters that are coupled. Unfortunately there was no decouple option. The main vessel shuts down and loss of control occurred. Unless there is another alternative the separation will need to occur when the vessel is completely stable.

There was another issue with the docking ports. When trying to make a connection the docking port refused. In the persistence file the ModuleDockingNode settings are PreAttached, Acquire Ready and Docked which can have various sub groups as (same vessel), (dockee) and (docker). 

The Preattched seems to be the issue. By resetting that back to Ready the port works. Acquire is unkown and requires testing on what this does.

By the way Gene was smiling even though the vessel did not make it to space. Bill and the team are very excited at this progress and will continue to pursue this method of rocket construction.

Construction of the next vessel will have four boosters. The thrust level of the inner is set to two thirds. The idea is if the vessel has loss of control due to undocking problems the inner boosters will continue to burn. 

![9gozy5U.png](http://i.imgur.com/9gozy5U.png)

Valentina was excited at seeing the boys break the limits and assemble their own rocket. She too is helping out and this area is called the Vehicle Assembly Lawn or VAL

Bob still grumbles about that name and that it is a very bad and trouble some idea. 

Bob: "Rocket construction should be left to those individuals who are qualified and properly trained, such as the personnel within the Vertical Assembly Building or the Space Plane Hanger. Besides the safety regulations that you are breaking..."

Jebediah: "Quiet Bob!"

![PGC1IGI.png](http://i.imgur.com/PGC1IGI.png)

During the construction of the test vessel many lessons were learned. 

The idea of using RCS to help with the final docking maneuvering has a downfall. The monopropellant reserve is used quickly. As an alternative Bill wants to use rocket power.

![5Ibo5Ml.png](http://i.imgur.com/5Ibo5Ml.png)

Without any action groups to turn engines on/off this manifold Bill designed allows forward and reverse, clockwise and anticlockwise. The twin docking ports enable/disable fuel flow with just a single click. Many engines can be controlled this way and even more ports can be added to fan out the engine control depending on the load being delivered.

Of course this part needs to be made modular so that it connects within the existing carriage frame.

[Bill Testing of the next generation controls.](https://vimeo.com/135723531)

[https://vimeo.com/135723531](https://vimeo.com/135723531)

The second test rocket was half way built then during a reload the docking ports became unusable. After reloading and returning to the launch pad the vessel vanished. This indicates the launch pad should not be used to house the core vessel. Depending on the complexity the core should be taken off the launch pad and held with mobile launch clamps. Then finish the vessel assembly at the VAL and return to the launch pad for firing.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-08T16:33:22Z" title="08/08/2015 04:33  PM" data-short="8 yr">August 8, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

From Bill's manifold design an accidental and groundbreaking discovery was made.

Bill demonstrates the principal.

![f7mYMbk.png](http://i.imgur.com/f7mYMbk.png)

External fuel docked to a core vessel's docking ports with attached fuel lines going in and out are very useful.

![ZtQ29W8.png](http://i.imgur.com/ZtQ29W8.png)

The centre fuel tank could have full fuel and none of it would be used as long as the valves are off.

![tmTHvu0.png](http://i.imgur.com/tmTHvu0.png)

Fuel ducts and docking ports are a caveman friend!

The Thumper and Thud are powerful caveman technology when used correctly.

Fuel flows through solid rocket boosters. With Thumpers being attached via docking ports the inner boosters will union a liquid fuel engine with gimbal and solid rocket boosters.

Jebediah saw this design of Bill's and wanted to try it out immediately.

After Bill finishes testing the design then Jebediah will be flying it.

![qe5BPDD.png](http://i.imgur.com/qe5BPDD.png)

Jebediah ready for launch.

![3BMOrdc.png](http://i.imgur.com/3BMOrdc.png)

Control authority from the Thuds.

![1HEpKzy.png](http://i.imgur.com/1HEpKzy.png)

With the Thuds off the control is lost.

![oSripuw.png](http://i.imgur.com/oSripuw.png)

Jebediah Loves Thuds And Thumpers

![wXsJAUq.gif](http://i.imgur.com/wXsJAUq.gif)

![qv9QmTd.png](http://i.imgur.com/qv9QmTd.png)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-08T16:12:29Z" title="08/08/2015 04:12  PM" data-short="8 yr">August 8, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/6rdQL)

![sqCb7mF.png](http://i.imgur.com/sqCb7mF.png)

![gDmXDI0.png](http://i.imgur.com/gDmXDI0.png)

![NZ30IPj.png](http://i.imgur.com/NZ30IPj.png)

![EJl99Rz.png](http://i.imgur.com/EJl99Rz.png)

![MR2XuC1.png](http://i.imgur.com/MR2XuC1.png)

![SfTxkwz.png](http://i.imgur.com/SfTxkwz.png)

![zZTrPKt.png](http://i.imgur.com/zZTrPKt.png)

The staging of boosters on decouplers and docking ports still has issues. The vessel focus was still lost upon booster separation using the decouplers. 

Bob:0.0: for the first time is offering to help Bill:) and will make a docking port model for them to investigate the issues and experiment on rocket construction order of operations. 

Bob:huh: has viewed the video of Bill:blush: assembling the latest rocket and has made the following observations.

Current order of operations:

1. truck launched at runway
2. twin boosters cart launched at runway truck attaches to it
3. another twin booster cart launched at runway truck and twin booster cart attached to it
4. rocket core launched at launch pad

Attachment order:

1. twin booster carts separated
2. twin booster cart attached to rocket
3. disconnect truck from cart
4. truck attaches to other twin booster cart
5. attach twin booster cart to rocket
6. disconnect truck from cart

Another observation:

Those RUTS and the windows damaged at the R&D building were created and will be repaired by Bill:P.

When Bill![k_angry.gif](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/images/smilies/k_angry.gif) decided to pay Bob![k_rolleyes.gif](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/images/smilies/k_rolleyes.gif) back for always dissing him and his ideas he did not know Bob![k_undecided.gif](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/images/smilies/k_undecided.gif) was going to review the video.

![vcYOpHo.gif](http://i.imgur.com/vcYOpHo.gif)

Bill:huh: has learned much before this success. 

Here is a video of previous events that occurred that gave him nightmares.

[Boosters & Rockets Swiped Kerbal Kidnapped](https://vimeo.com/136123672)

<iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/136123672" width="874" height="482" frameborder="0" title="Bill Has Nightmares" allowfullscreen="true"></iframe>

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-12T21:43:55Z" title="08/12/2015 09:43  PM" data-short="8 yr">August 12, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

Bob:) and Bill:cool: have made some progress.

 They have a test vehicle that is a snap to assemble and it has provided some interesting data.

> [Javascript is disabled. View full album](//imgur.com/a/jhd9x)

The Hammer pictured on the right seems to always have vessel focus lost when it is undocked.

It was placed onto the probe second to last. Separated from the tow truck then Bill:wink: had to rocket wrangle it into place. The Flea was then attached by driving the tow truck forward.

The docking port that is at the top of the probe core was the root part.

The tow truck was launched and then two rocket carts. The probe was launched last. 

Bob:) plans on further testing and wants Bill:huh: to place the Flea on as well.

The undock separates stages that are connected by docking ports and the vessel focus will switch to the booster being released.

This will sometimes cause the probe to shut down the engine,SAS control and the "control from here" point is switched to the docking port after switching back to the probe vessel.

The decouple has never done this in addition the top and bottom ports are released resulting in a clean break.

![tvSBaAN.png](http://i.imgur.com/tvSBaAN.png)

The decouple is also a mystery as to how that becomes an option. Too bad Bill:mad: could not hit it with his 2.5 kg negotiator and knock those docking ports to the proper setting.

The undock can give clean break as well but so far the logic for it has yet to be understood. All three Fleas and two Hammers undocked without losing focus. Just that one Hammer caused problems.

Perhaps Bob:rolleyes: and Bill:0.0: will need to converse with a gray bearded wise wizard:cool: who has dealt with and understands docking ports differently.

[The details for this vessel are here.](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/131321-Vehicle-Assembly-Lawn?p=2136917#post2136917)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-14T03:35:39Z" title="08/14/2015 03:35  AM" data-short="8 yr">August 14, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

Today Bob:huh: is trying to understand the logic of docking ports and underocking the ports.

When loss of vessel focus occurs and mission control is receiving the wrong telemetry data Gene:rolleyes: does not panic but it does makes him upset.

While Bob:wink: is designing the test jig he accidentally places a LV-T30 Reliant on top of a docking port.

The docking port was one of three that were radially attached.

Bill:0.0: notices something and exclaims "Let me take over. That can be transformed into a big whopper booster block! ".

![SM75myq.png](http://i.imgur.com/SM75myq.png)

Above the Big Whopper is the inspiration. 

 This booster block will be fabricated using a combo of LV-T30 and LV-T45 and stage engines.

 The radial attached Thud were to be used but this design has more power at sea level and much better ISP above atmosphere.

We can clearly see that since the union of Bob and Bill there seems to be a new chapter developing in their quest for Duna.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-08-14T17:57:31Z" title="08/14/2015 05:57  PM" data-short="8 yr">August 14, 2015</time> by MoeslyArmlis**

Bob:huh: seems to understand why the separation of docking ports occurs. 

 Bob:) and Bill:D designed this mock up to test out his theory.

![EfYKpSr.png](http://i.imgur.com/EfYKpSr.png)

Bill:wink: is happy because he wanted to build a crane for some time now.

Jebediah:cool: and Valentina:D top the rocket.

![julNJY9.png](http://i.imgur.com/julNJY9.png)

Total teamwork.

![LDd15Im.png](http://i.imgur.com/LDd15Im.png)

![8jvYzEv.png](http://i.imgur.com/8jvYzEv.png)

![B78mZUE.png](http://i.imgur.com/B78mZUE.png)

![hbdDbYA.png](http://i.imgur.com/hbdDbYA.png)

![gOVMFZN.png](http://i.imgur.com/gOVMFZN.png)

Bob:cool: was accurate and the booster separated without losing vessel focus. The last part docked was the upper probe core and when that was decoupled the SAS was disabled but focus remained on the probe core. When the Spark was decoupled that is when vessel focus was lost. Focus was switched to the docking port attached to the Spark.

This marks another new beginning. The team now can build rockets that have proper staging. Gene:) is much more confident that a rock(et probe) will get to Duna and does not mind the ruts being dug into the lawn.

[Rocket Details](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/131321-Vehicle-Assembly-Lawn?p=2140633&viewfull=1#post2140633)

Here is the assembly video.

[Team Tops A Rocket](https://vimeo.com/136450917)
